titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Van Wyck family papers 1978.064
titlestmt.author: Dee Bowers

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-01-05 19:30:36 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Van Wyck family papers contain four wills and one estate inventory, primarily related to Huntington, Long Island.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This small collection is housed in a single folder with no particular arrangement.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: The Van Wycks were an aristocratic family originally from Holland who were a prominent part of New York history. Members of the Van Wyck family served in the Revolutionary and Civil Wars, and also held both local and national political positions.

list.head: Source:
list.item: "The O'Donnell Site: Anthropology research." New York State Museum, c. 2011-2016. www.nysm.nysed.gov/research/anthropology/crsp/projects/odonnell.html

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); Van Wyck family papers, 1978.064, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and described by Dee Bowers in 2023.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The New York Public Library holds the Van Cortlandt-Van Wyck family papers (MssCol 3130). There is also a collection of Van Wyck family papers at the Dutchess County Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Van Wyck family papers contain four wills and one estate inventory. This branch of the family lived primarily in Huntington, Long Island. The wills are for Theodorus (1844), Elizabeth (1822), Richard (1837), and Abraham (1809) Van Wyck. The inventory is of Abraham's estate.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The materials in this collection are in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
